description: C++ first appeared over 30 years ago, and remains popular to this day. This series aims to teach viewers how to use C++ without any prior knowledge.
descriptionMD: C++ first appeared over 30 years ago, and remains popular to this day. This series aims to teach viewers how to use C++ without any prior knowledge.
name: Intro to C Plus Plus
subtitle: General purpose programming language

episodes.description: In this episode, we will briefly go over the history of C++, what it is like in comparison to other programming languages, how to compile a C++ source file, and how to set up your computer for C++ development
episodes.title: Overview And Environment Setup
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.780 --> 00:00:16.216
Greetings everyone, and welcome to
another exciting episode of DevProTV.

3
00:00:16.216 --> 00:00:18.385
I'm your host, Justin Dennison.

4
00:00:18.385 --> 00:00:21.235
And in today's episode, well, we've got
a very special treat planned for you.

5
00:00:21.235 --> 00:00:25.575
We're starting Intro to C++, so
you better buckle up and hang on.

6
00:00:25.575 --> 00:00:28.790
And here to help us with that very
endeavor is Mr. Jacob Armstrong.

7
00:00:28.790 --> 00:00:29.695
How you doing today, Jacob?

8
00:00:29.695 --> 00:00:31.275
>> Very good, Justin, how are you?

9
00:00:31.275 --> 00:00:36.395
>> I am doing fantastic, I'm
particularly excited about this series,

10
00:00:36.395 --> 00:00:40.747
because I know C++ is kinda
the ideology of performance.

11
00:00:40.747 --> 00:00:45.170
Games, scientific programming,
which is kind of some of my background.

12
00:00:45.170 --> 00:00:48.200
If you wanna go fast,
you kinda gotta reach down into the metal.

13
00:00:48.200 --> 00:00:53.800
Now that's about the extent that I know,
so what exactly is C++?

14
00:00:53.800 --> 00:00:58.890
>> So to give a brief overview, C++ is
a programming language made in the 1980s

15
00:00:58.890 --> 00:01:05.280
by a Dutch computer scientist named, might
mispronounce this, Bjarne Stroustrup.

16
00:01:05.280 --> 00:01:09.109
It is sort of the next iteration on C.

17
00:01:09.109 --> 00:01:13.270
They are two separate programming
languages, C and C++.

18
00:01:13.270 --> 00:01:19.542
The joke is that the ++ operator
is a go up one operator,

19
00:01:19.542 --> 00:01:23.605
so C++ can be thought of as C up one.

20
00:01:23.605 --> 00:01:29.611
So C++ is a compiled
objected-oriented language.

21
00:01:29.611 --> 00:01:32.877
Compiled means that it takes source
code that you write in text, and

22
00:01:32.877 --> 00:01:35.960
turns into machine code
whenever you compile it.

23
00:01:35.960 --> 00:01:40.929
And object-oriented means that
it is not procedural, basically.

24
00:01:40.929 --> 00:01:45.022
It used to be that programming
languages were sort of monolithic.

25
00:01:45.022 --> 00:01:49.783
You'd have the whole program in one file,
and people would get method names mixed

26
00:01:49.783 --> 00:01:53.105
up, they'd have variables
being named the same thing.

27
00:01:53.105 --> 00:01:54.645
It was kind of a pain to debug.

28
00:01:54.645 --> 00:01:59.406
So the solution to that was to create
object-oriented languages where we

29
00:01:59.406 --> 00:02:03.840
would have data encapsulated
inside objects and classes.

30
00:02:03.840 --> 00:02:05.440
>> Now Jacob,
I can actually speak to this.

31
00:02:05.440 --> 00:02:07.860
I've worked on some legacy projects.

32
00:02:07.860 --> 00:02:10.939
Legacy code is all kinds of
fun where the entire program,

33
00:02:10.939 --> 00:02:13.090
it wasn't necessarily in one file.

34
00:02:13.090 --> 00:02:15.530
There was one function per file.

35
00:02:15.530 --> 00:02:18.410
And the functions were like
300 to 400 lines long,

36
00:02:18.410 --> 00:02:22.410
and then everything kind of compiled,
there was 160 files.

37
00:02:22.410 --> 00:02:26.180
It was a nightmare,
mainly because everything was global.

38
00:02:26.180 --> 00:02:29.403
People were using global variables for
logging and debugging.

39
00:02:29.403 --> 00:02:34.618
And I will tell you, I got it working
kinda, but it would have saved me a great

40
00:02:34.618 --> 00:02:41.310
deal of heart ache if that actual project
had been structured a little differently.

41
00:02:41.310 --> 00:02:45.487
>> Right, and while we will go over
the details of object-oriented languages

42
00:02:45.487 --> 00:02:50.072
later, for now let's just actually try
to get some C++ working on your machine.

43
00:02:50.072 --> 00:02:55.910
So here on my computer I'm gonna
download a compiler for C++.

44
00:02:55.910 --> 00:02:59.575
So if I go to the Internet real quick.

45
00:02:59.575 --> 00:03:05.800
I'm gonna get specifically
the Windows GNU compiler, right now.

46
00:03:05.800 --> 00:03:09.740
And we aren't gonna use command line
compiling for all of our projects.

47
00:03:09.740 --> 00:03:14.440
I just want to show you this in case
you want to know sort of the more low

48
00:03:14.440 --> 00:03:16.513
level way to compile things.

49
00:03:16.513 --> 00:03:19.038
Or, if you're not on Windows,

50
00:03:19.038 --> 00:03:24.193
how you could compile things on
the command line for Linux or Mac.

51
00:03:24.193 --> 00:03:28.619
So here we go,
I believe the name is called WinGW.

52
00:03:33.238 --> 00:03:34.731
MinGW, I'm sorry.

53
00:03:34.731 --> 00:03:38.710
That stands for
Minimum GNU Compiler for Windows.

54
00:03:38.710 --> 00:03:42.177
So let's go on the official site,
right here.

55
00:03:42.177 --> 00:03:44.670
So there's two places that
you can go to download this.

56
00:03:44.670 --> 00:03:49.740
Up here in the top right corner,
there is a Downloads tab.

57
00:03:49.740 --> 00:03:54.483
And toward the bottom in the navigation
pane here there is also a Downloads

58
00:03:54.483 --> 00:03:57.401
option, so we're just gonna click on that.

59
00:04:01.444 --> 00:04:08.240
And we want to get the latest
version of MinGWgitsetup.exe.

60
00:04:08.240 --> 00:04:11.562
Now I've already gone ahead and
downloaded this,

61
00:04:11.562 --> 00:04:14.585
so once you get this,
you're going to run it.

62
00:04:14.585 --> 00:04:18.777
And I also have screenshots,
though, of the running process.

63
00:04:18.777 --> 00:04:25.358
So bear with me as I open them up,
and here we go.

64
00:04:27.939 --> 00:04:29.326
So here we are.

65
00:04:29.326 --> 00:04:32.590
Let me just get this out
of behind my head if I can.

66
00:04:35.160 --> 00:04:36.175
Thank you.

67
00:04:36.175 --> 00:04:40.317
So first thing that happens is,
this is the last page actually.

68
00:04:40.317 --> 00:04:44.566
This is the last thing that happens,
I think.

69
00:04:44.566 --> 00:04:48.630
Hold on, so I don't know how to
use Windows actually, I'm sorry.

70
00:04:48.630 --> 00:04:50.281
Let's start from here.

71
00:04:50.281 --> 00:04:54.022
First you're gonna have a just
general licensing agreement.

72
00:04:54.022 --> 00:05:00.665
So if you are okay with everything in
here, you will hit Install at the bottom.

73
00:05:00.665 --> 00:05:02.361
And then after installing,

74
00:05:07.811 --> 00:05:11.660
You'll have to decide where you want to
install it, this is actually important.

75
00:05:11.660 --> 00:05:14.490
You're gonna wanna remember this so
that you can set environment variables, so

76
00:05:14.490 --> 00:05:17.590
that the command line actually
knows what programs to run.

77
00:05:17.590 --> 00:05:22.442
Here there is a user interface option, I
have elected not to get the user interface

78
00:05:22.442 --> 00:05:27.107
for this, because I am just using a
compiled command line version to compile.

79
00:05:27.107 --> 00:05:31.296
But if you wanna download that user
interface and play with it a little bit,

80
00:05:31.296 --> 00:05:32.760
go right ahead.

81
00:05:32.760 --> 00:05:35.947
And once you hit Continue
it will begin to download.

82
00:05:37.739 --> 00:05:44.139
So once this is done, you can go ahead and
hit Quit down here at the bottom right.

83
00:05:44.139 --> 00:05:50.849
And you'll have MinGW
on your local machine.

84
00:05:50.849 --> 00:05:54.294
We can't actually compile
anything quite yet.

85
00:05:54.294 --> 00:05:59.206
First we actually do need to set
an environment variable form engine

86
00:05:59.206 --> 00:06:02.308
that GW so
that the command line knows where

87
00:06:02.308 --> 00:06:06.420
to find the command lines
that we're going to be using.

88
00:06:06.420 --> 00:06:08.399
>> Now Jacob,
let me cut in here just a little bit.

89
00:06:08.399 --> 00:06:12.539
This MinGW, this is gonna be a very
similar experience if you're in a command

90
00:06:12.539 --> 00:06:16.510
line in a Linux environment, correct,
or am I totally off base there?

91
00:06:16.510 --> 00:06:17.750
>> You're absolutely correct.

92
00:06:17.750 --> 00:06:21.265
Linux environments that we're gonna
be using the same GNU libraries that

93
00:06:21.265 --> 00:06:21.955
Windows are.

94
00:06:21.955 --> 00:06:26.520
This is just sort of a GNU library for
Windows specifically.

95
00:06:26.520 --> 00:06:30.621
We're gonna be using a G++ command.

96
00:06:30.621 --> 00:06:31.380
Linux will do the same thing more or less.

97
00:06:33.100 --> 00:06:36.670
So this is more of a Windows specific
thing that you have to do right now,

98
00:06:36.670 --> 00:06:38.900
setting up your environment variables.

99
00:06:38.900 --> 00:06:44.189
So we're gonna go onto the Windows tab and
type in My Computer.

100
00:06:49.479 --> 00:06:51.639
Actually in Windows 10
it's gonna be This PC.

101
00:06:51.639 --> 00:06:54.359
So you're gonna right-click on this and
go to Properties.

102
00:06:59.031 --> 00:07:03.660
And in Properties, we're gonna go
to the Advanced System Settings.

103
00:07:03.660 --> 00:07:07.041
And in Advanced System Settings, we're
going to go to Environment Variables.

104
00:07:09.889 --> 00:07:12.093
So here's a list of
environment variables for me,

105
00:07:12.093 --> 00:07:15.050
you should see something
similar on your machine.

106
00:07:15.050 --> 00:07:19.901
Under System Variables, here are a bunch
of things that you already have.

107
00:07:19.901 --> 00:07:23.867
What we're gonna do specifically
is edit the path variable.

108
00:07:23.867 --> 00:07:25.772
This is the path variable, and

109
00:07:25.772 --> 00:07:29.893
here is a bunch of paths that
are already installed on my computer.

110
00:07:29.893 --> 00:07:31.493
Let's go to Edit here.

111
00:07:34.757 --> 00:07:37.435
And we're going to add
a new environment variable.

112
00:07:39.312 --> 00:07:41.776
But before we actually do this,

113
00:07:41.776 --> 00:07:45.989
we need to get that bin of the MinGW,
so let's do that.

114
00:07:45.989 --> 00:07:50.629
If I remember correctly from my own
install, that was under my C drive.

115
00:07:55.454 --> 00:07:57.550
And right here, MinGW.

116
00:07:57.550 --> 00:08:00.678
You're gonna double-click on this,
go into it.

117
00:08:00.678 --> 00:08:03.444
And go into the bin.

118
00:08:03.444 --> 00:08:05.920
And we're going to copy this.

119
00:08:05.920 --> 00:08:08.560
I already downloaded some stuff,
so my bin is already full.

120
00:08:08.560 --> 00:08:12.860
You should only have one thing in
here by the time that you are,

121
00:08:12.860 --> 00:08:14.510
when you're at the same
place I am basically.

122
00:08:14.510 --> 00:08:19.609
So we're gonna copy this, go back into
our environment variable settings.

123
00:08:20.700 --> 00:08:22.310
And paste it in here.

124
00:08:22.310 --> 00:08:24.230
I've already done that.

125
00:08:24.230 --> 00:08:27.150
I've got my MainGW.bin right
here where I need it to be.

126
00:08:28.510 --> 00:08:30.990
After you do this you will need
to restart your computer so

127
00:08:30.990 --> 00:08:33.700
that Windows knows where this is.

128
00:08:33.700 --> 00:08:35.780
And it can just get setup done.

129
00:08:35.780 --> 00:08:39.213
So if you are listening to the recorded
version of this you can go ahead and

130
00:08:39.213 --> 00:08:40.969
pause it and restart your computer.

131
00:08:40.969 --> 00:08:44.734
Now Jacob, let me just make sure,
that path that we're adding to the path

132
00:08:44.734 --> 00:08:47.180
variable from your
environment in variables.

133
00:08:47.180 --> 00:08:51.168
Number one, Windows 10 has made this a lot
easier than previous versions of Windows.

134
00:08:51.168 --> 00:08:54.306
Cuz it used to be this giant string that
you had to kind of concatenate on the end

135
00:08:54.306 --> 00:08:55.871
of and you didn't have enough space.

136
00:08:55.871 --> 00:09:00.467
So that's slick, but also, that's gonna be
dependent on your installation directory

137
00:09:00.467 --> 00:09:03.350
from the previous install steps,
am I right in that?

138
00:09:03.350 --> 00:09:04.240
>> Yes absolutely.

139
00:09:04.240 --> 00:09:08.815
If you don't install
MinGW under your C drive,

140
00:09:08.815 --> 00:09:13.270
if you install it somewhere else, you
will need to go to that MinGW folder and

141
00:09:13.270 --> 00:09:17.540
into that bin inside that MinGW
folder instead of where I did it.

142
00:09:17.540 --> 00:09:20.770
The only thing that matters
is that you get that bin,

143
00:09:20.770 --> 00:09:22.780
the path to that bin in the correct spot.

144
00:09:23.860 --> 00:09:28.017
So once you're done restarting, I'm
gonna assume that you already done that,

145
00:09:30.245 --> 00:09:32.372
You should be ready to go for a compile.

146
00:09:34.293 --> 00:09:39.360
So to compile a C++ program, we actually
need to write some C++ source code.

147
00:09:39.360 --> 00:09:41.600
So let's get started on that for
an example.

148
00:09:41.600 --> 00:09:44.700
We're just gonna write a very
simple Hello World program.

149
00:09:46.690 --> 00:09:49.818
I'm just going to create a new text
file right here on my desktop.

150
00:09:55.886 --> 00:10:01.957
And we're going to name it
not New Text Document.txt,

151
00:10:01.957 --> 00:10:06.879
we're going to name this helloworld.cpp.

152
00:10:06.879 --> 00:10:09.536
It's gonna complain that we
are changing the name extension.

153
00:10:09.536 --> 00:10:12.690
We don't care,
we want it to be a .cpp file.

154
00:10:12.690 --> 00:10:17.690
A .cpp extension means that
it is a C++ source file.

155
00:10:17.690 --> 00:10:20.940
This is what we wanna do.

156
00:10:20.940 --> 00:10:24.668
Now if you do initially make
it a .txt file, that's okay,

157
00:10:24.668 --> 00:10:26.243
you can change it later.

158
00:10:26.243 --> 00:10:30.232
But will wanna make sure that you
have file extensions shown under

159
00:10:30.232 --> 00:10:31.618
your folder options.

160
00:10:31.618 --> 00:10:36.887
Actually I made that mistake,
not to recently ago

161
00:10:36.887 --> 00:10:42.291
where I almost tried to
compile a .CPP.txt file.

162
00:10:42.291 --> 00:10:44.350
>> That will happen,
I've had things like that.

163
00:10:44.350 --> 00:10:47.275
And another common error that I've made.

164
00:10:47.275 --> 00:10:50.790
Is it has to be plain text it can't
have any rich text format in it.

165
00:10:50.790 --> 00:10:53.420
It can't be,
you can't do this in Word, and

166
00:10:53.420 --> 00:10:56.416
then change the file
extension from like a .docx.

167
00:10:56.416 --> 00:11:00.955
Otherwise, you'll have all this meta data
that's embedded in the top portion of

168
00:11:00.955 --> 00:11:04.522
the file that, well you're gonna
have a whole bunch of not fun.

169
00:11:04.522 --> 00:11:09.249
So has to be plain text and
all plain text means is it is text only.

170
00:11:09.249 --> 00:11:13.509
There's no markup, there's no rendering
options, there's no styling, whatnot.

171
00:11:13.509 --> 00:11:17.084
As long as you're using notepad or
creating a new text document as was shown,

172
00:11:17.084 --> 00:11:18.940
you should be fine.

173
00:11:18.940 --> 00:11:23.000
>> Right, so
now we're going to open it up in Notepad

174
00:11:23.000 --> 00:11:26.840
because that is a very
simple text editor program.

175
00:11:27.910 --> 00:11:28.830
And we're going to get started.

176
00:11:29.930 --> 00:11:31.440
So, Hello World.

177
00:11:31.440 --> 00:11:33.770
The Hello World Program is going
to do basically one thing,

178
00:11:33.770 --> 00:11:36.240
it's going to find
a console output window.

179
00:11:36.240 --> 00:11:40.170
And it's going to push
Hello World into that window.

180
00:11:40.170 --> 00:11:43.590
You may not understand
exactly what I'm typing in.

181
00:11:43.590 --> 00:11:45.880
I'll try to explain it as I go along.

182
00:11:45.880 --> 00:11:49.230
But the main details of this,
we're gonna cover in later lessons.

183
00:11:49.230 --> 00:11:50.520
This is just to get compiling done.

184
00:11:51.730 --> 00:11:53.360
So let's get started.

185
00:11:53.360 --> 00:11:56.440
First thing we're gonna
want is a main function.

186
00:11:59.405 --> 00:12:05.175
Main() is a special function in C++ and
in some other programming languages.

187
00:12:05.175 --> 00:12:08.170
Main() is where your
program initially starts.

188
00:12:08.170 --> 00:12:11.144
Without a main method,
your program won't know where to start.

189
00:12:13.716 --> 00:12:17.137
>> Now, Jacob, let me jump in there just
a little bit, just so we can make sure,

190
00:12:17.137 --> 00:12:19.980
is there any way to make that
text just a little bit bigger?

191
00:12:19.980 --> 00:12:22.840
I know I'm being nit picky here.

192
00:12:22.840 --> 00:12:23.350
Yeah.

193
00:12:23.350 --> 00:12:24.310
>> Can do.

194
00:12:24.310 --> 00:12:28.260
>> So, it's kinda of weird, this is
actually simulating some styling but

195
00:12:28.260 --> 00:12:32.040
this isn't changing
the underlying text styling.

196
00:12:32.040 --> 00:12:34.190
Yeah there we go, we should be good there.

197
00:12:34.190 --> 00:12:36.400
I'm going to now,
slink away into the shadows.

198
00:12:36.400 --> 00:12:38.580
>> Hopefully,
you won't have to squint anymore.

199
00:12:38.580 --> 00:12:42.875
So main() return 0,
which means that after main is done,

200
00:12:42.875 --> 00:12:46.090
it will spit back out
a 0 to whoever calls it.

201
00:12:46.090 --> 00:12:47.881
That's just nonsense,
it doesn't really matter.

202
00:12:47.881 --> 00:12:50.506
Don't worry about it.

203
00:12:50.506 --> 00:12:55.404
So before that, we're gonna do std,
which stands for standard, this is

204
00:12:55.404 --> 00:13:00.618
a standard namespace, a namespace being
just a way to hold a bunch of classes,

205
00:13:00.618 --> 00:13:05.129
and objects, and variables, and
stuff together in a logical way.

206
00:13:05.129 --> 00:13:10.498
And inside standard,
we are gonna go inside it with a colon,

207
00:13:10.498 --> 00:13:15.781
colon, we are gonna do,
cout that stands for console out.

208
00:13:15.781 --> 00:13:19.492
We're gonna use this,
a less than less than symbol,

209
00:13:19.492 --> 00:13:25.602
which is called a pipe operator, and we're
going to type pipe into console out, this.

210
00:13:29.655 --> 00:13:31.830
If I can spell world correctly.

211
00:13:31.830 --> 00:13:37.520
And then after that, we're going to
type into cout a standard end line.

212
00:13:37.520 --> 00:13:40.200
And this'll just create an entry so
it looks nice.

213
00:13:41.430 --> 00:13:44.360
But actually this won't work as it is.

214
00:13:44.360 --> 00:13:49.310
If we try to compile this right now,
it'll say I don't know what cout is, and

215
00:13:49.310 --> 00:13:50.900
I don't know what endl is.

216
00:13:50.900 --> 00:13:54.827
Because we haven't imported
the input output stream library.

217
00:13:58.072 --> 00:13:59.840
So to import things
we're gonna do include.

218
00:13:59.840 --> 00:14:02.550
We'll talk about importing
things later in detail.

219
00:14:02.550 --> 00:14:06.184
This is just basically what
we're doing right now,

220
00:14:06.184 --> 00:14:10.079
is bringing in the input
output classes and variables.

221
00:14:15.703 --> 00:14:20.080
Include says to bring this in,
and this is iostream.

222
00:14:20.080 --> 00:14:20.920
So we should be good to go.

223
00:14:20.920 --> 00:14:21.920
This should compile.

224

00:15:27.690 --> 00:15:32.464

So we're gonna type in now is

249

world.cpp file by going g++,
which is the compiler,

250

we're gonna compile Hello World.cpp.

it looks like we have

These are things that you may encounter,

00:17:01.490 --> 00:17:04.780
And, well,
the compiled languages typically say,

262
00:17:04.780 --> 00:17:09.150
hey, you're probably gonna wanna look

263
00:17:09.150 --> 00:17:10.800

So let's open back up Notepad, I opened it

00:20:11.410 --> 00:20:12.760
>> Yeah, absolutely.

315
00:20:12.760 --> 00:20:17.320
Notepad is just a basic text editor,
it's not really made to write code.

316
00:20:17.320 --> 00:20:21.710
But there are programs out there that
are actually made to write code.

317
00:20:21.710 --> 00:20:23.200
They're called IDEs.

00:20:23.200 --> 00:20:25.920
Once again,
those are integrated design environments.

One of those, for Windows at least,

00:20:28.570 --> 00:20:31.910
The community version of
Visual Studio is free,

to write C+ code in the future.

322
00:20:36.020 --> 00:20:40.520
And one of the nice things about Visual
Studio is that you don't have to manually

00:20:40.520 --> 00:20:42.100

324
00:20:42.100 --> 00:20:44.840
There's a button you can click and
it just does that for you, and

00:20:47.230 --> 00:20:48.830
So, Visual Studio.

let's just search for Visual Studio.

00:21:50.695 --> 00:21:52.634

00:22:01.320 --> 00:22:05.510

00:22:05.510 --> 00:22:10.010

00:22:28.200 --> 00:22:28.760

Quick forewarning for those of you who

00:22:48.120 --> 00:22:49.000

Can we compile something?

Visual Studio Code is the text editor, and

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Jacob will explore the creation of variables as well as functions for breaking up some of the complexities of code.
episodes.title: Variables and Functions

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Jacob will explore the creation of functions in C++. Jacob also highlights some of the considerations that need to be made when writing functions including parameter types, return types, and naming.
episodes.title: Variables and Functions Pt2

episodes.description: In this episode, we will go over classes, objects, and some ways to use them.
episodes.title: Classes

episodes.description: In this episode, we will go over scope: its definition, how it works, and some best-practice ways to use it.
episodes.title: Scope

episodes.description: In this episode, we will go over statements that allow you to control how a program is executed.
episodes.title: Control Flow Statements

episodes.description: This episode will be about pointers, the data type that points to the memory addresses of other data.
episodes.title: Pointers

episodes.description: In this episode, we will talk about how classes can inherit their methods and variables from other classes, and how this can be used to reuse code.
episodes.title: Inheritance

episodes.description: In this episode, we discuss polymorphism, the concept of classes being the same data type as their parents
episodes.title: Polymorphism

episodes.description: In this episode, we will go over arrays, the most basic structure for storing data.
episodes.title: Arrays
